Federated Learning via Active RIS Assisted Over-the-Air Computation

Deyou Zhang*, Ming Xiao*, Mikael Skoglund*, and H. Vincent Poor§ *Division of Information Science and Engineering, KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm 10044, Sweden
§Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, USA
email: {deyou, mingx, skoglund}@kth.se; poor@princeton.edu
Abstract

In this paper, we propose leveraging the active reconfigurable intelligence surface (RIS) to support reliable gradient aggregation for over-the-air computation (AirComp) enabled federated learning (FL) systems. An analysis of the FL convergence property reveals that minimizing gradient aggregation errors in each training round is crucial for narrowing the convergence gap. As such, we formulate an optimization problem, aiming to minimize these errors by jointly optimizing the transceiver design and RIS configuration. To handle the formulated highly non-convex problem, we devise a two-layer alternative optimization framework to decompose it into several convex subproblems, each solvable optimally. Simulation results demonstrate the superiority of the active RIS in reducing gradient aggregation errors compared to its passive counterpart.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, over-the-air, reconfigurable intelligent surface, active RIS.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising distributed machine learning alternative to centralized learning approaches [1]. Orchestrated by an edge server, FL enables multiple edge nodes to collaboratively train a shared model without directly unveiling raw data. Specifically, FL operates in an iterative manner consisting of two primary steps: 1) The edge server disseminates a global model parameter vector to edge nodes for distributed on-device training with their local data. 2) These edge nodes upload their locally computed model parameter vectors to the edge server to update the global model parameter vector as a weighted average of the local vectors. Since only model parameter vectors rather than raw data are aggregated at the edge server, FL avoids prohibitive data transmission delay and mitigates potential privacy disclosure.

Despite the considerable advantages of FL, uploading local model parameter vectors to the edge server via conventional orthogonal multiple access (OMA) schemes can be resource-intensive, emerging as a potential bottleneck in FL. Though a number of works have proposed optimizing the communication and computation resources of edge nodes to enhance model uploading efficiency [2, 3, 4], they did not exploit the waveform-superposition property of the multiple-access channel, thus not fully harnessing the benefits of wireless communications. As an alternative, over-the-air computation (AirComp) has been recently introduced to enable simultaneous local model uploading over shared radio resources [5].

Unlike OMA schemes that allocate orthogonal radio resources such as time or bandwidth to edge nodes for independent transmission, the radio resources required by AirComp-enabled model uploading are independent of the number of edge nodes, significantly enhancing communication efficiency and system scalability. Despite these advantages, AirComp-enabled FL suffers from model aggregation errors caused by wireless fading and noise [6, 7, 8, 9, 10]. Existing works in this area avoided large aggregation errors mainly by excluding “stragglers”, i.e., devices with weak channels, from concurrent model uploading [6, 7]. For example, the authors in [6] proposed a truncated-based power control scheme to discard devices in deep fading. However, discarding devices from training reduces the number of training data, inevitably compromising learning performance, especially when the discarded devices possess unique data samples.

To cope with the straggler issue and mitigate potential degradation in learning performance caused by large aggregation errors, an alternative strategy is to strengthen the communication channels between stragglers and the edge server using advanced communication technologies, such as relays [11] or passive reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) [12, 13, 14]. For instance, the authors in [12] proposed to jointly optimize device selection, transceiver design, and RIS configuration to partially alleviate the straggler issue in FL. Though with some merits, the “multiplicative fading” effect curtails the benefits of passive RISs. To overcome such a fundamental limitation of passive RISs, a novel RIS architecture named active RIS has appeared [16, 15]. Unlike its passive counterpart, the active RIS is capable of amplifying its reflected signals through integrated reflection-type amplifiers in its reflecting elements.

In this paper, we focus on the AirComp-enabled FL system and propose utilizing active RIS to control gradient aggregation errors during training. Firstly, we analyze the convergence property of the considered FL system and derive an upper bound on the expected difference between the training loss and the optimal loss. This analysis reveals that minimizing the mean squared error (MSE) between the target global gradient vector and the received one is crucial for narrowing the convergence gap. Subsequently, we aim to minimize the MSE by jointly optimizing the transceiver design and RIS configuration. To address such a highly non-convex optimization problem, we introduce a two-layer alternative optimization (AO) strategy to decompose the original problem into several convex subproblems, each optimally solvable. Finally, we employ the MNIST dataset to assess learning performance in the context of the handwritten digit recognition task. Experiment results demonstrate the superiority of the active RIS in reducing gradient aggregation errors compared to its passive counterpart.

Global model dissemination: The edge server disseminates the current global model parameter vector 𝒘[t]superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑡\bm{w}^{[t]} to the K𝐾K edge nodes.

Local gradient computation: Upon receiving 𝒘[t]superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑡\bm{w}^{[t]}, each edge node uses its own dataset to compute a local gradient vector:

Such a procedure is repeated for a maximum number of T𝑇T rounds or until the global consensus, i.e., (1b), is achieved.

II-B Active RIS with SI

To improve the channel quality between the edge server and the U𝑈U edge nodes, we propose deploying an N𝑁N-element active RIS in the wireless FL system, as shown in Fig. 2. As such, the equivalent channel between the edge server and each edge node now consists of three links, i.e., the device-server link, the device-RIS link, and the RIS-server link.

Moreover, since the RIS works in full-duplex mode, the self-interference (SI) occurs. By denoting the signal impinging on the active RIS as 𝒙insubscript𝒙in\bm{x}_{\rm in}, the reflected signal of the active RIS in the presence of SI, 𝒙outsubscript𝒙out\bm{x}_{\rm out}, can be modeled as follows [15]

𝒙out=(𝑰−𝚽​𝑯)−1​𝚽​(𝒙in+𝒛A).subscript𝒙outsuperscript𝑰𝚽𝑯1𝚽subscript𝒙insubscript𝒛𝐴\bm{x}_{\rm out}=(\bm{I}-\bm{\Phi}\bm{H})^{-1}\bm{\Phi}\left(\bm{x}_{\rm in}+\bm{z}_{A}\right). (7)

In (7), 𝚽=diag​(β1​ej​θ1,⋯,βN​ej​θN)𝚽diagsubscript𝛽1superscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝜃1⋯subscript𝛽𝑁superscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝜃𝑁\bm{\Phi}={\rm diag}\left(\beta_{1}e^{j\theta_{1}},\cdots,\beta_{N}e^{j\theta_{N}}\right) is the reflection coefficient matrix of the active RIS, where βnsubscript𝛽𝑛\beta_{n} and θnsubscript𝜃𝑛\theta_{n} respectively denote the amplification factor and phase shift of the n𝑛n-th RIS element. It is worth mentioning that βnsubscript𝛽𝑛\beta_{n} can be larger than one due to the integrated reflection-type amplifier in active RISs. In addition, 𝑯∈𝒞N×N𝑯superscript𝒞𝑁𝑁\bm{H}\in\mathcal{C}^{N\times N} in (7) is the SI channel, and 𝒛A∼(𝟎,σA2​𝑰)similar-tosubscript𝒛𝐴0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐴2𝑰\bm{z}_{A}\sim\left(\bm{0},\sigma_{A}^{2}\bm{I}\right) is the thermal noise introduced at the active RIS. Regarding 𝑯𝑯\bm{H}, we assume each of its elements follows 𝒞​𝒩​(0,ν2)𝒞𝒩0superscript𝜈2{\cal CN}(0,\nu^{2}), and when all of its elements are small, we can approximate (7) as follows

𝒙out≈(𝑰+𝚽​𝑯)​𝚽​(𝒙in+𝒛A).subscript𝒙out𝑰𝚽𝑯𝚽subscript𝒙insubscript𝒛𝐴\bm{x}_{\rm out}\approx(\bm{I}+\bm{\Phi}\bm{H})\bm{\Phi}\left(\bm{x}_{\rm in}+\bm{z}_{A}\right). (8)

II-C AirComp-Enabled Gradient Aggregation

As mentioned earlier, to reduce the communication overhead, we adopt AirComp for gradient aggregation. That is, the U𝑈U edge nodes transmit their respective local gradient vectors to the edge server using the same time-frequency resources at each training round. In the following, we will elaborate on the details.

First of all, each edge node normalizes its computed local gradient vector via

Note that in (9), we have omitted the training round index t𝑡t for brevity. 𝕄​𝕊​𝔼​(s^,s)=𝔼​(|s^−s|2).𝕄𝕊𝔼^𝑠𝑠𝔼superscript^𝑠𝑠2\mathbb{MSE}(\hat{s},s)=\mathbb{E}\left(|\hat{s}-s|^{2}\right). (15)

Upon obtaining s^^𝑠\hat{s}, we use it to recover g𝑔g, i.e., the typical entry associated with 𝒈𝒈\bm{g}, via

g^=1K​(s^+∑i=1Ug¯i).^𝑔1𝐾^𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈subscript¯𝑔𝑖\hat{g}=\frac{1}{K}\left(\hat{s}+\sum\limits_{i=1}^{U}\bar{g}_{i}\right). (16)

The MSE between g^^𝑔\hat{g} and g𝑔g is then given by

𝕄​𝕊​𝔼​(g^,g)=𝔼​(|g^−g|2)=𝔼​(|s^−s|2)K2.𝕄𝕊𝔼^𝑔𝑔𝔼superscript^𝑔𝑔2𝔼superscript^𝑠𝑠2superscript𝐾2\mathbb{MSE}(\hat{g},g)=\mathbb{E}\left(|\hat{g}-g|^{2}\right)=\frac{\mathbb{E}\left(|\hat{s}-s|^{2}\right)}{K^{2}}. (17)

III Convergence Analysis and Problem Formulation

This section analyzes the convergence property of the considered wireless FL system, which motivates the proposed transceiver and RIS configuration design, as detailed below.

III-A Convergence Analysis

To proceed, we first make the following two standard assumptions.

Assumption 1

The loss function L​(⋅)𝐿⋅L(\cdot) is uniformly Lipschitz continuous with parameter ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0, such that for any 𝐰,𝐰′∈ℛd×1𝐰superscript𝐰′superscriptℛ𝑑1\bm{w},\bm{w}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{R}^{d\times 1}, we have

L​(𝒘′)≤L​(𝒘)+(𝒘′−𝒘)T​∇L​(𝒘)+ρ2​‖𝒘′−𝒘‖2.𝐿superscript𝒘′𝐿𝒘superscriptsuperscript𝒘′𝒘𝑇∇𝐿𝒘𝜌2superscriptnormsuperscript𝒘′𝒘2L(\bm{w}^{\prime})\leq L(\bm{w})+\left(\bm{w}^{\prime}-\bm{w}\right)^{T}\nabla L(\bm{w})+\frac{\rho}{2}\left\|\bm{w}^{\prime}-\bm{w}\right\|^{2}. (18)
Assumption 2

The loss function L​(⋅)𝐿⋅L(\cdot) is strongly convex with respect to the parameter μ>0𝜇0\mu>0, such that for any 𝐰,𝐰′∈ℛd×1𝐰superscript𝐰′superscriptℛ𝑑1\bm{w},\bm{w}^{\prime}\in{\cal R}^{d\times 1}, we have

L​(𝒘′)≥L​(𝒘)+(𝒘′−𝒘)T​∇L​(𝒘)+μ2​‖𝒘′−𝒘‖2.𝐿superscript𝒘′𝐿𝒘superscriptsuperscript𝒘′𝒘𝑇∇𝐿𝒘𝜇2superscriptnormsuperscript𝒘′𝒘2L(\bm{w}^{\prime})\geq L(\bm{w})+\left(\bm{w}^{\prime}-\bm{w}\right)^{T}\nabla L(\bm{w})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{w}^{\prime}-\bm{w}\right\|^{2}. (19)

Based on the above two assumptions, we have the following theorem.

Theorem 1

Suppose Assumptions 1 and 2 are valid and the learning rate η𝜂\eta is set to be ρ−1superscript𝜌1{\rho}^{-1} for each training round. Then, after T≥1𝑇1T\geq 1 training rounds, the expected difference between the training loss L​(𝒘[T+1])𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑇1L(\bm{w}^{[T+1]}) and the optimal loss L​(𝒘⋆)𝐿superscript𝒘⋆L(\bm{w}^{\star}) can be upper bounded by

𝔼​[L​(𝒘[T+1])−L​(𝒘⋆)]≤𝔼​[L​(𝒘[1])−L​(𝒘⋆)]​λT𝔼delimited-[]𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑇1𝐿superscript𝒘⋆𝔼delimited-[]𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]1𝐿superscript𝒘⋆superscript𝜆𝑇\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}[L(\bm{w}^{[T+1]})-L(\bm{w}^{\star})]\leq{\mathbb{E}}[L(\bm{w}^{[1]})-L(\bm{w}^{\star})]~{}\lambda^{T}
+∑t=1TλT−t2​ρ​𝔼​(‖𝒈^[t]−𝒈[t]‖2),superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝜆𝑇𝑡2𝜌𝔼superscriptnormsuperscriptbold-^𝒈delimited-[]𝑡superscript𝒈delimited-[]𝑡2\displaystyle+\sum\limits_{t=1}^{T}\frac{\lambda^{T-t}}{2\rho}\mathbb{E}(\|\bm{\hat{g}}^{[t]}-\bm{g}^{[t]}\|^{2}), (20)

where 𝒘⋆superscript𝒘⋆\bm{w}^{\star} denotes the optimal model parameter vector and λ≜1−μ/ρ≜𝜆1𝜇𝜌\lambda\triangleq 1-\mu/\rho.

Proof:

Refer to Appendix A. ∎

Moreover, since μ<ρ𝜇𝜌\mu<\rho, which implies 0<λ<10𝜆10<\lambda<1, when T→∞→𝑇T\to\infty, λT→0→superscript𝜆𝑇0\lambda^{T}\to 0, and we can therefore simplify (1) as follows

𝔼​[L​(𝒘[T+1])−L​(𝒘⋆)]≤∑t=1TλT−t2​ρ​𝔼​(‖𝒈^[t]−𝒈[t]‖2).𝔼delimited-[]𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑇1𝐿superscript𝒘⋆superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝜆𝑇𝑡2𝜌𝔼superscriptnormsuperscriptbold-^𝒈delimited-[]𝑡superscript𝒈delimited-[]𝑡2{\mathbb{E}}[L(\bm{w}^{[T+1]})-L(\bm{w}^{\star})]\leq\sum\limits_{t=1}^{T}\frac{\lambda^{T-t}}{2\rho}\mathbb{E}(\|\bm{\hat{g}}^{[t]}-\bm{g}^{[t]}\|^{2}). (21)

It can be observed from (21) that FL recursions over wireless channels still converge, though a gap a,between L​(𝒘⋆)𝐿superscript𝒘⋆L(\bm{w}^{\star}) and limT→∞𝔼​[L​(𝒘[T+1])]subscript→𝑇𝔼delimited-[]𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑇1\lim\nolimits_{T\to\infty}{\mathbb{E}}[L(\bm{w}^{[T+1]})] exists due to gradient errors.

III-B Problem Formulation

To improve the performance of the considered wireless FL system, as shown in (21), we need to minimize the gradient errors in each training round. To this end, we construct the following optimization problem:

min𝒎,𝒃,𝚽subscript𝒎𝒃𝚽\displaystyle\min\limits_{\bm{m},\bm{b},\bm{\Phi}}~{} 𝕄​𝕊​𝔼​(s^,s)𝕄𝕊𝔼^𝑠𝑠\displaystyle\mathbb{MSE}(\hat{s},s) (22a)
s.t. |bi|2≤Pi,∀i∈𝒰,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖2subscript𝑃𝑖for-all𝑖𝒰\displaystyle|b_{i}|^{2}\leq P_{i},~{}\forall i\in\mathcal{U}, (22b)
𝔼​(‖𝒓‖2)≤PA,𝔼superscriptnorm𝒓2subscript𝑃𝐴\displaystyle\mathbb{E}(\|\bm{r}\|^{2})\leq P_{A}, (22c)

where 𝒃=[b1,⋯,bU]T𝒃superscriptsubscript𝑏1⋯subscript𝑏𝑈𝑇\bm{b}=[b_{1},\cdots,b_{U}]^{T}, and (22b), (22c) account for the maximum power constraints for each edge node and the active RIS, respectively, with Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}, ∀i∈𝒰for-all𝑖𝒰\forall i\in\mathcal{U} denoting the maximum power of edge node i𝑖i, and PAsubscript𝑃𝐴P_{A} denoting that of the active RIS. Moreover, we employ 𝕄​𝕊​𝔼​(s^,s)𝕄𝕊𝔼^𝑠𝑠\mathbb{MSE}(\hat{s},s) instead of 𝕄​𝕊​𝔼​(g^,g)𝕄𝕊𝔼^𝑔𝑔\mathbb{MSE}(\hat{g},g) as the objective function since minimizing 𝕄​𝕊​𝔼​(g^,g~)𝕄𝕊𝔼^𝑔~𝑔\mathbb{MSE}(\hat{g},\tilde{g}) is equivalent to minimizing 𝕄​𝕊​𝔼​(s^,s~)𝕄𝕊𝔼^𝑠~𝑠\mathbb{MSE}(\hat{s},\tilde{s}), as shown in (17).

IV Alternative Optimization for Transceiver and RIS Configuration Design

To proceed, we follow the existing literature [9, 13, 12] and assume {𝒔i}subscript𝒔𝑖\{\bm{s}_{i}\} are independent of each other, such that both (22a) and (22c) will possess a closed-form expression. =∑i=1U|𝒎H​𝒉e,i​bi−Ki​δi|2+σA2​‖𝒎H​𝑮​𝚿‖2+σE2​‖𝒎‖2,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈superscriptsuperscript𝒎𝐻subscript𝒉𝑒𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐴2superscriptnormsuperscript𝒎𝐻𝑮𝚿2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐸2superscriptnorm𝒎2\displaystyle=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{U}\left|\bm{m}^{H}\bm{h}_{e,i}b_{i}-K_{i}\delta_{i}\right|^{2}+\sigma_{A}^{2}\|\bm{m}^{H}\bm{G}\bm{\Psi}\|^{2}+\sigma_{E}^{2}\|\bm{m}\|^{2},
𝔼​(‖𝒓‖2)=∑i=1U|bi|2​‖𝚿​𝒉r,i‖2+σA2​Tr​(𝚿​𝚿H)≤PA.𝔼superscriptnorm𝒓2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖2superscriptnorm𝚿subscript𝒉𝑟𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐴2Tr𝚿superscript𝚿𝐻subscript𝑃𝐴\displaystyle\mathbb{E}(\|\bm{r}\|^{2})=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{U}|b_{i}|^{2}\|\bm{\Psi}\bm{h}_{r,i}\|^{2}+\sigma_{A}^{2}{\rm Tr}(\bm{\Psi}\bm{\Psi}^{H})\leq P_{A}. With (23) and (24), it is still challenging to solve (22) due to the coupling among 𝒎𝒎\bm{m}, 𝒃𝒃\bm{b}, and 𝚽𝚽\bm{\Phi}. In the sequel, we resort to the AO technique to address this issue, which only optimizes one variable at a time, as detailed below.

It is observed that (28) is a quadratically constrained quadratic program (QCQP), and off-the-shelf solvers such as CVX can be used to solve this problem optimally.

In the sequel, we recall the AO technique and optimize ϕ≜diag​(𝚽)≜bold-italic-ϕdiag𝚽\bm{\phi}\triangleq{\rm diag}(\bm{\Phi}) and ϕ~≜diag​(𝚽~)≜bold-~bold-italic-ϕdiagbold-~𝚽\bm{\tilde{\phi}}\triangleq{\rm diag}(\bm{\tilde{\Phi}}) alternatively until ϕ=ϕ~bold-italic-ϕbold-~bold-italic-ϕ\bm{\phi}=\bm{\tilde{\phi}} is achieved.

From (33a), we can compute the optimal ϕbold-italic-ϕ\bm{\phi} as

where the nonnegative Lagrange multiplier λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2} can be determined through the one-dimensional grid search to satisfy (38b) and (38c).

Thus far, we have introduced the proposed transceiver and RIS configuration design approach and the whole procedures are summarized in Algorithm 1 for clarity.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we present numerical results to demonstrate the effectiveness of deploying active RIS in enhancing the performance of the AirComp-enabled FL system. We adopt a three-dimensional coordinate configuration, where the locations of the edge server and the active RIS are set to (−50,0,10)50010\left(-50,0,10\right) meters and (0,0,10)0010\left(0,0,10\right) meters, respectively, and the U=20𝑈20U=20 edge nodes are uniformly distributed in the region of ([0,20],[−10,10],0)02010100\left([0,20],[-10,10],0\right) meters. Each link in {𝒉r,i}subscript𝒉𝑟𝑖\{\bm{h}_{r,i}\}, {𝒉d,i}subscript𝒉𝑑𝑖\{\bm{h}_{d,i}\}, and 𝑮𝑮\bm{G} is subjected to both path loss and small-scale fading. The path loss model is given by PL​(ξ)=C0​(ξ/ξ0)−κPL𝜉subscript𝐶0superscript𝜉subscript𝜉0𝜅\textsf{PL}(\xi)=C_{0}\left(\xi/\xi_{0}\right)^{-\kappa}, where C0=30subscript𝐶030C_{0}=30 dB denotes the path loss at the reference distance of ξ0=1subscript𝜉01\xi_{0}=1 meter, ξ𝜉\xi represents the link distance, and κ𝜅\kappa is the path loss component. Throughout the simulations, the path loss components for {𝒉r,i}subscript𝒉𝑟𝑖\{\bm{h}_{r,i}\}, {𝒉d,i}subscript𝒉𝑑𝑖\{\bm{h}_{d,i}\}, and 𝑮𝑮\bm{G} are set to 2.82.82.8, 3.63.63.6, and 2.22.22.2, respectively. For small-scale fading, we employ the standard Rician channel model, assigning Rician factors of 00, 00, and 333 dB to {𝒉r,i}subscript𝒉𝑟𝑖\{\bm{h}_{r,i}\}, {𝒉d,i}subscript𝒉𝑑𝑖\{\bm{h}_{d,i}\}, and 𝑮𝑮\bm{G}, respectively. Furthermore, we set M=10𝑀10M=10, N=200𝑁200N=200, Pi=0subscript𝑃𝑖0P_{i}=0 dB, ∀i∈𝒰for-all𝑖𝒰\forall i\in\mathcal{U}, PA=0subscript𝑃𝐴0P_{A}=0 dB, σA2=−80superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐴280\sigma_{A}^{2}=-80 dB, σE2=−80superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐸280\sigma_{E}^{2}=-80 dB, and ν=−30𝜈30\nu=-30 dB.

To evaluate learning performance, we use the MNIST dataset to simulate the handwritten digit recognition task [18]. Specifically, we train a fully connected neural network with 784784784 inputs and 101010 outputs, using cross-entropy as the loss function, which yields a total of d=7840𝑑7840d=7840 model parameters. The set of K=60,000𝐾60000K=60,000 training data samples is equally divided into 404040 shards of size 150015001500 in a non-IID manner, and we assign each edge node two shards without replacement as its local dataset, i.e., Ki=3000subscript𝐾𝑖3000K_{i}=3000, ∀i∈𝒰for-all𝑖𝒰\forall i\in\mathcal{U}. The test dataset consists of 10,0001000010,000 samples, and we evaluate learning performance using test accuracy, defined as number of correctly recognized handwritten digits10000number of correctly recognized handwritten digits10000\frac{\text{number of correctly recognized handwritten digits}}{10000}. Moreover, the number of training rounds T𝑇T is set to be 505050, and the learning rate η[t]=0.05superscript𝜂delimited-[]𝑡0.05\eta^{[t]}=0.05, ∀t=1,⋯,Tfor-all𝑡1⋯𝑇\forall t=1,\cdots,T.

In Fig. 3, we plot 𝔼​(‖𝒈^[t]−𝒈[t]‖2)/d𝔼superscriptnormsuperscriptbold-^𝒈delimited-[]𝑡superscript𝒈delimited-[]𝑡2𝑑\mathbb{E}\left(\|\bm{\hat{g}}^{[t]}-\bm{g}^{[t]}\|^{2}\right)/d, ∀t=1,⋯,Tfor-all𝑡1⋯𝑇\forall t=1,\cdots,T. From this figure, it is immediately apparent that the active RIS can significantly reduce the errors in gradient aggregation compared to FL without RIS, whereas the passive RIS achieves only limited improvement. Consequently, we can deduce that the active RIS is more efficient than its passive counterpart in enhancing the performance of the AirComp-enabled FL system, as corroborated by Fig. 3.

VI Conclusions

In this paper, we have proposed an active RIS assisted AirComp technique to support gradient aggregation in wireless FL systems. Our analysis of the FL convergence property has revealed that minimizing gradient aggregation errors in each training round is pivotal to reducing the convergence gap. As such, we have developed an AO approach for the joint optimization of the transceiver design and RIS configuration in each training round. Experiment results have demonstrated that the active RIS significantly reduced gradient aggregation errors compared to its passive counterpart, thereby leading to superior learning performance.

Referring to [17], when the loss function L​(𝒘)𝐿𝒘L(\bm{w}) is uniformly Lipschitz continuous with parameter ρ𝜌\rho and the learning rate η[t]=1/ρsuperscript𝜂delimited-[]𝑡1𝜌\eta^{[t]}={1}/{\rho}, the following inequality holds:

L​(𝒘[t+1])≤L​(𝒘[t])−12​ρ​‖∇L​(𝒘[t])‖2+12​ρ​‖𝒆[t]‖2,𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑡1𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑡12𝜌superscriptnorm∇𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑡212𝜌superscriptnormsuperscript𝒆delimited-[]𝑡2L(\bm{w}^{[t+1]})\leq L(\bm{w}^{[t]})-\frac{1}{2\rho}\|\nabla L(\bm{w}^{[t]})\|^{2}+\frac{1}{2\rho}\|\bm{e}^{[t]}\|^{2}, (40)

where 𝒆[t]=𝒈^[t]−𝒈[t]superscript𝒆delimited-[]𝑡superscriptbold-^𝒈delimited-[]𝑡superscript𝒈delimited-[]𝑡\bm{e}^{[t]}=\bm{\hat{g}}^{[t]}-\bm{g}^{[t]} is the gradient error. Moreover, from (19), we can derive that

‖∇L​(𝒘[t])‖2≥2​μ​[L​(𝒘[t])−L​(𝒘⋆)].superscriptnorm∇𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑡22𝜇delimited-[]𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑡𝐿superscript𝒘⋆\|\nabla L(\bm{w}^{[t]})\|^{2}\geq 2\mu[L(\bm{w}^{[t]})-L(\bm{w}^{\star})]. (41)

By substituting (41) into (40), we have

L​(𝒘[t+1])𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑡1\displaystyle L(\bm{w}^{[t+1]})
≤L​(𝒘[t])−(μ/ρ)​[L​(𝒘[t])−L​(𝒘⋆)]+12​ρ​‖𝒆[t]‖2.absent𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑡𝜇𝜌delimited-[]𝐿superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑡𝐿superscript𝒘⋆12𝜌superscriptnormsuperscript𝒆delimited-[]𝑡2\displaystyle~{}~{}\leq L(\bm{w}^{[t]})-({\mu}/{\rho})~{}[L(\bm{w}^{[t]})-L(\bm{w}^{\star})]+\frac{1}{2\rho}\|\bm{e}^{[t]}\|^{2}. (42)

Next, by first subtracting L​(𝒘⋆)𝐿superscript𝒘⋆L(\bm{w}^{\star}) and then taking expectation on both sides of (A), we obtain that

(43)

Applying (A) recursively for t=T,⋯,1𝑡𝑇⋯1t=T,\cdots,1, we prove (1) and complete the proof.
